Problem:
Consider a system of differential equations defined by \(\dot{z} = Cz\), where \(z \in \mathbb{C}^n\) and \(C\) is a complex matrix. We explore the effect of a Fourier transform \(\mathcal{F}\{z(t)\}\) applied at a certain time.

If at some \(t_1\), an operation such as another Fourier transform is applied as an intervention, will \(z(T)\) at \(T > t_1\) uniquely reflect the properties and rules of the original matrix \(C\) only?
Explanation: Introducing another Fourier transform modulates the system differently, adding another layer of transformation. This makes the final state \(z(T)\) a combination influenced by \(C\), the original \(\mathcal{F}\{z_0\}\), and the second Fourier transform. Thus, \(z(T)\) depends collectively on multiple factors, not just \(C\).
